author: .vbuterin
content: If we optimize for read-only we could potentially even just use a single commitment instead of a verkle tree

author: .vbuterin
content: I think realistically, even the current epoch is going to have to be verkle

author: .vbuterin
content: The witness sizes are just too large with binary trees

author: .vbuterin
content: And yeah, as you mentioned, the recalculation complexity for using two different commitment schemes is pretty high

author: .vbuterin
content: Also, in-place accumulator swap mechanisms are not efficiently verifiable, which violates an important invariant that we're trying to go for (each individual block transition can be efficiently verified)

author: .vbuterin
content: Unless we can snark it, which we could do with some schemes, but I think with verkle might be too hard
